msContents.summary: Greek fragment of Isocrates containing the concluding lines of Panegyricus (par. 189) and the beginning lines of De Pace (pars. 1-3)

msItemStruct.note: Side 1: 15 lines written on the hair side
Side 2: 16 lines written on the flesh side
Upright mid-sized uncials, literary hand of the so-called biblical type (Grenfell and Hunt); a few corrections, stops, and breathing marks in a darker ink by a later hand
Contains the end of Panegyricus (ll. 1-3) with a concluding title line (l. 4), and the beginning of De Pace (ll. 6-33) with an initial title line (l. 5)
Text is not a close match to any medieval MS of Isocrates
Pap. 6, Special Collections, Luce Library, Princeton Theological Seminary, Princeton, N.J.

supportDesc.support: 10 x 7.3 cm. A nearly complete leaf of very thin vellum; extensive surface puckering; severe discoloration at edges; one small, loose fragment has been rejoined to the body of the leaf.

provenance.p: Excavated by Grenfell and Hunt for the Egypt Exploration Fund in 1906; donated to Princeton Theological Seminary in 1915 through an arrangment with Prof. William Park Armstrong.

div.ab: [Side 1:] They regard them as the cause of great blessings to others. *PANEGYRIC* *CONCERNING THE PEACE* All those who customarily come forward here say that the greatest things and the things most worthy of attention by the city are the things that they are about to advise you. Nevertheless, even if it were appropriate to preface some other matters with such words, it seems fitting to me, with respect to the present state of affairs [Side 2:] to make a beginning in this way. For we have assembled today concerning war and peace, which have utmost power in the life of men, and concerning which those who are counseled rightly necessarily manage better than others. So great, then, is the magnitude of the things for which we have come together. But I see that you do not give an equal hearing to the speakers, but you give attention to some, while to others not
